Ken, Rich - 

This seems to be the situation today with the doubling of NBTHK shinsa costs a year or so ago. Today, I would only submit a tsuba to shinsa if the signature was important enough to make the tsuba "valuable" enough to justify the costs. One tsuba here that I'm considering sending to shinsa is mumei but if judged "Akasaka" and perhaps designated to a particular generation, in my eyes, it would justify the cost of shinsa. Bob Benson mentioned awhile back that a lot of people are acquiring only Hozon papers and not bothering with paying for Tokubetsu shinsa, simply to "confirm" the mei. 

Personally, I am an advocate of papers being gotten on "priority" items in my collection. 

Ron
STL

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: alchemyst 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, July 10, 2003 12:24 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: papering tsuba


  Ken -

  My feeble thoughts on the topic. I have several papered
  tsuba; all purchased with papers. Papers aren't my thing.
  But I do plan on submitting two or three at the next US
  shinsa just to get opinions on school and age. IMHO
  unless it is a matter of verifying a mei of a famous
  maker; getting info is the main reason for submitting for
  papers. I agree that at the current rates, especially for
  the NBTHK, it is not feasible to submit anything but very
  high grade fittings. The cost of the shinsa is more than
  the fittings (even with papers) would be worth in most cases.
  Just my humble $0.03 worth (to allow for inflation)

  Rich
